title: Albert G. Lee
text:
Lieutenant Colonel Sir Albert George Lee <a href="Military%20Cross">MC</a> (24 May 1879 – 26 August 1967) was a <a href="Great%20Britain">British</a> <a href="radio">radio</a> pioneer.
Lee was born in <a href="Conwy">Conwy</a>, <a href="Wales">Wales</a>, and in 1903 entered the <a href="General%20Post%20Office">General Post Office</a> Engineering Service, where he designed and tested submarine and other cables. In <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> he served in the Royal Engineers (Signal Service) commanding a telegraph construction company, and later was Officer-in-Charge, General Headquarters Signal Area. In 1920 Lee became involved with radios, and soon became Staff Engineer in charge of the radio section of the General Post Office. He was associated with the development of a coupled circuit arc, the <a href="Rugby%2C%20Warwickshire">Rugby, Warwickshire</a> high-power station, and the transatlantic telephone and shortwave telephone service.
Lee was a member of the <a href="Institution%20of%20Electrical%20Engineers">Institution of Electrical Engineers</a>, and chaired its Wireless Section from 1927 to 1928. He was elected a Fellow of the <a href="Institute%20of%20Radio%20Engineers">Institute of Radio Engineers</a> in 1929, knighted in the <a href="1937%20New%20Year%20Honours">1937 New Year Honours</a> and awarded the <a href="IEEE%20Medal%20of%20Honor">IRE Medal of Honor</a> in 1939 "for his accomplishments in promoting international radio services and in fostering advances in the art and science of radio communication."
